question: Question_04_(iii)
statement:
Consider the function

\[f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\]

iii) Find the x-values of all the inflection points of f(x).

\emph{Note: if inflection points do not exist, say so.}
sols:
The previous part gave us that

\[\displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.\]

Let's compute the second derivative of the function:

\[\displaystyle
f''(x) = 3x^2 -12x + 9\] and then factor it

\begin{align*}
f''(x) &= 3x^2 -12x + 9\\
&= 3(x^2-4x+3) \\
&= 3(x-1)(x-3)
\end{align*}

This is plenty enough to get the sign table of the second derivative.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& & $\displaystyle 1$ & & $\displaystyle 3$ &\\
$\displaystyle 3(x-1)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$\\
Â~$\displaystyle (x-3)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
Â~$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
Â~$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \cup$ & & $\displaystyle \cap$ &
& $\displaystyle \cup$\\\\
\end{longtable}

And so we see that there are two inflection points, one at \emph{x} = 1
and one at \emph{x} = 3.
